This may rule out several of the female candidates: Natalia Gherman is Moldovan, and has expressed some sympathy with Ukraine, and opposition to greater integration of Moldova and Russia (Moldova also faces an ongoing crisis over the Russian-backed, break-away republic of Transnistria). Irina Bokova, on the other hand, is a Bulgarian who is known to have close personal links to the Kremlin, and therefore risks opposition from the anti-Russia consensus. The most likely Eastern European woman to win the appointment, therefore, is Vesna Pusic - is a Croat who has spoken out about mending relations with Russia; however, she is also a prominent advocate of LGBT rights (where she is clearly not in line with the Kremlin). She would seem to be a good compromise candidate. If we continue to run with the Eastern European theory, then we need to evaluate the chances of Pusic against the 5 Eastern European men who are also in the running: the Serbian, Montenegrin, and Macedonian candidates are all seen as being, to varying degrees, close to Russia. The Slovakian candidate also has some links to the Kremlin, and in recent months has led Slovak negotiations with Russia in spite of EU sanctions. The Slovenian candidate has an honourary doctorate from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations, and is popular in the Russian press; however, he may be seen as the best male compromise candidate between Russia and the West, not least because of his track record in promoting rapprochement with Russia.
